organic_results.title: School composition and learning: A critique of the Dreeben-Barr model
organic_results.snippet: Dreeben and Barr point out that social scientists generally posit normative and comparative reference-group processes as the mechanism that links school composition to students' academic achievement and college aspirations (see Figure 1). In empirical studies, school composition usually is measured as the racial composition of schools, mean socioeconomic status, or mean achievement. Although these studies have failed to document consistent or strong referencegroup influences, social scientists have seemed reluctant to abandon the …
